𓃡 dogger gir₁₅ in 𒌨𒂠 ur-gir₁₅ •kir₄ 𓃡 κύon 𒆠 kiᵒⁿ in 𒌨𒆠 ur-ki 𓃡 κύon ⇔ 𒆲 kun kvn kavn kabn 𓐍 𓃀 𓄢 "tail" 𓃡 κύon ⇔ 𒆲 kun 𒆪𒌦 ku-un хайуан canavar կենդանի kendani гынник gynnik জানোয়ার janoẏar "animal"

𓃹 𓈖 𓃀 𓃢 •Cuon alpinus "white dog" <> 𓃹 𓈖 cunīculus κόνικλος kóniklos „kleiner Kuon“ 犬 𓃹 𓈖 𓈙 𓃥 čono šağâl شغال jackal wolf in 𓋴 𓃀 𓃢 •sιbör > цөөвөр чоно cöövör čono 𓃹 𓈖 𓃥 ≈ 𒌨𒌨 chini chenille canīcula “little dog” "caterpillar"

𒌨𒆠𒉌 hal-ki-ni ḪUL.κύon 犬 quǎn chien canis @ Elamite ⇔ karne 𓃹

𓃩 Dagan 𒀭𒅎 𒀭𒁕𒃶 originally a weather-god

First animal to be domesticated by man.

An extinct Late Pleistocene wolf which may have been the ancestor of the dog split from other wolf lineages between 20,000 and 40,000 years ago. Domestication must have occured later. The Bonn-Oberkassel dog buried beside humans 14,200 years ago is the first undisputed dog. The dog was domesticated in Eurasia, either Central Asia, East Asia or Western Europe.

ANE Ancient North Eurasian

"It has been suggested that their mythology may have included a narrative, found in both Indo-European and Native American fables, in which a dog guards the path to the afterlife." wiki

Domestication of the dog in Siberia?

Doctors

Two Eurasian (+American) mysts:
1.) Keeper of Hell
2.) Doctors ⇔ DogTier

Nintinuga was the Babylonian goddess of medicine and wife of the god Ninurta 𒀭𒊩𒌆 𒅁. The goddess is identifying with the Acad goddess Bau (𒀭𒁀𒌑 Dbau) or Baba and accompanied or represented by dogs ⇔ Humbaba?
Gula after the First Babylonian Dynasty.

The most prominent cult centre of 𒀭𒊩𒌆𒋼𒀀𒊏𒀝 Gula/Ninkarrak/Ninisinna was Isin 𒉌𒋛𒅔𒆠,
where her temple as named 𒂍𒌑𒂠𒊏 é-u-gi7-ra "Dog Temple"

犬 quǎn > kū 哭 吅犬 口 koǔ quǎn PIE √ḱwö(n) ‘dog’
call > howl haó 号 hū 呼 口乎 koǔ hū

In the Sumerian cryptography known as UD.GAL.NUN the sign KU substitutes for DOG (Krebernik 1998: 300)
KU für UR kommt jedoch auch außerhalb der UGN-Orthogrophie vor, so daß sich die Grenzen zwischen Normal- und UGN nicht ganz scharf ziehen lassen.
